questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the office for her first prenatal visit. Her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. The patient has had nausea and vomiting occasionally over the past few weeks but no other symptoms. Supine blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg and 138/92 mm Hg on repeat measurement 15 minutes later. Physical examination shows an anxious woman with mild bilateral ankle edema and an enlarged uterus. A urinalysis dipstick is negative for protein and glucose. The patient returns to the office for a blood pressure measurement a week later and her blood pressure is 152/106 mm Hg.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypertension is defined as a systolic blood pressure 140 mm Hg and/or a diastolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg. Chronic hypertension predates pregnancy but can be diagnosed any time before 20 weeks gestation To make a diagnosis of chronic hypertension during pregnancy, blood pressure should be elevated at 2 measurements taken 4 hours apart. This patient presents with elevated_ blood pressure during 2 separate office visits before 20 weeks gestation and meets criteria for chronic hypertension.

questions.text: A 30 years old primigravida with 32 weeks of gestation with microcytic hypochromic anaemia of 6 gm%. She is hemodynamically stable but has history of easy fatiguability for 4-5 months. She is also giving history of passage of worms in stool. What should be the best line of management in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Deworming and iron sucrose

Severe anemia in early third trimester (<34 weeks) is an indication of injectable iron therapy by iron sucrose or ferric carboxymaltose. Albendazole is safe in pregnancy. It should be given to all patients of IDA.

choices.text: Continue oral anti coagulation till active labour
Switch over to inj. Heparin immediately
Switch over to inj. Heparin at 36 weeks
Give vitamin k since this is overdosage of oral anticoagulation

questions.text: A 35 years old G2P1L1 has 24 weeks of gestation. She is a known case of rheumatic heart disease with history of valve replacement surgery done 10 years back for which she is on oral anti-coagulant therapy. Her PT (INR) is 2.0. What is the next best plan of action regarding her anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Switch over to inj. Heparin at 36 weeks

Warfarin is an oral anti-coagulant used in pregnancy. It should be avoided in first trimester for the risk of fetal warfarin syndrome and it should be stopped at 36 weeks so that the baby should not have warfarin in its body during the process of delivery as it may cause intra ventricular hemorrhage in the baby and PPH in the mother

choices.text: Balanced translocation in patient and partner

questions.text: A 32 years old nulliparous patient had history of 3 abortions in last 3 years. All her abortions were spontaneous and were of 8-9 weeks. What is the possible cause amongst the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Balanced translocation in patient and partner

Cervical incompetence and syphilis can never cause recurrent first trimester abortions. These conditions can cause second trimester abortion. Fibroid can cause recurrent abortion only if it invades the uterine cavity or distorts the uterine cavity. Sub-serosal pedunculated fibroids are not known to cause recurrent abortions. Genetic cause of RPL with balanced translocation is a well-known cause of RPL though it is very rare.

choices.text: It is more common in hypertensive patients
It is more common in smokers
USG is diagnostic in most cases
PV examination can be done in abruptio placenta

questions.text: One of the following is not the clinical feature of abruptio placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

USG is diagnostic in most cases

Most common cause of abruptio is hypertension in pregnancy. Smoking and cocaine addiction are the risk factors. PV exam and ARM are done in abruptio case. USG is not diagnostic since it can detect only 25-35% cases of abruptio. Abruptio is a clinical diagnosis.

questions.text: One of the following is not associated with placenta previa:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Primigravida

Placenta previa is seen in multiparous patient. It is not associated with primigravida commonly

choices.text: Progesterone production is not dependent on foetus
Estriol formation requires raw material from fetal origin
HPL is directly proportional to the size of placenta

questions.text: One of the following is not true regarding hormones in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HCG is luteolytic hormone

HCG is a luteotropic hormone. It is related to LH with similar action. It protects the corpus luteum in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old had a baby with Down syndrome 10 years ago. She is anxious to know the chromosome status of her fetus in a current pregnancy. The test that has the fastest lab processing time for karyotype is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amniocentesis, cordocentesis, cystic hygroma aspiration, and chorionic villus sampling are techniques of obtaining fetal tissues that are amenable to cytogenetic analysis. Amniotic fluid cells require tissue culture to obtain adequate cell numbers for analysis. Chorionic villi can be harvested directly for extremely rapid diagnosis or can be cultured for higher banding (increased detail). Fetal blood obtained by cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) requires 2 to 3 days of culturing before a karyotype is obtained. Doppler flow ultrasound is used to assess blood flow through fetal vessels, but is not a substitute for direct analysis of tissue.

questions.text: Which type of pelvis is associated with persistent OP
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following describes the reproductive history of a pregnant woman who is 32 weeks pregnant with a previous twin delivery at 34 weeks where one baby died after 1 day and other is alive and healthy and a still birth at 32 weeks
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Following a cesarean birth, contraindications for a trial of labor in a subsequent pregnancy include all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Guidelines from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists state that a patient with a prior low transverse cesarean section may attempt a vaginal delivery following informed consent to the risks involved. Although the issue of prior cesarean section for CPD is controversial, this prior procedure is not an absolute contraindication for a trial of labor. A classic incision is a contraindication because of a high risk of uterine rupture. X-ray pelvimetry is not required prior to a trial of labor; a prior vaginal delivery is not necessary either.

questions.text: Dose of dexamethasone and interval
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: What are the findings in the image shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of bishops score
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bishops score has 5 components these are cervical dilatation, cervical effacement, position of cervix, consistency of cervix and station of head. Type of pelvis is not component of bishops

questions.text: All the following can be findings in a woman who was followed up after suction evacuation for molar pregnancy and has the following chest X ray image except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A primigravida with preeclampsia at 37 weeks is being induced with oxytocin. The following graph is seen during her monitoring. Which of the following will not be done for her management ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which of the following findings would deter you from offering this patient a trial of breech delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fetal weight of 4,100 g is a relative contraindication to offering a trial of breech delivery. The criteria recommended to offer a trial of breech labor include an adequate pelvis as determined by pelvimetry and imaging (generally X-ray, CT, or MRI), frank or complete breech, a flexed fetal head, and estimated fetal weight of 2,500 to 3,800 g. Relative contraindications to offering a vaginal breech trial of labor include weight greater than 3,800 g, nulliparity, and incomplete breech, such as footling breech presentation.

choices.text: Prolonged use of oxytocin during labor
Prolonged exposure to magnesium during labor

questions.text: Which of the following are not risk factors for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PPH in the context of vaginal delivery is defined as an estimated blood loss greater than 500 mL. Most of all PPH s results from uterine atony, the failure of uterine muscles to contract normally after the second and third stages of labor. Without muscular contraction, severed vessels of the placental bed will continue to bleed. Any factor that might cause uterine muscle exhaustion or distend and distort the muscle can cause atony. These factors allow prediction of PPH and preparation of uterotonic medications prior to delivery. Advanced maternal age is not associated with PPH, although it can be associated with multiparity and the development of preeclampsia requiring magnesium

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks of gestation by her LMP, presents to you for an ultrasound examination to confirm her due date. Which of the following measurements on the fetus is the best at predicting her actual due date?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In the second trimester (over 13 weeks), BPD is the most accurate at determining actual gestational age. CRL length is the most accurate in the fi rst trimester. None of the other measurements is as useful at estimating gestational age except for the head circumference

choices.text: Tube on the affected side must be intact.
The gestation sac must be in the position of the ovary
The gestation sac is connected with infundibulopelvic ligament
Ovarian tissue must be found on its wall on histological examination.

questions.text: The spiegelberg’s criteria in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The gestation sac is connected with infundibulopelvic ligament

The Spiegelberg criteria are four criteria used to identify ovarian ectopic pregnancies  named after Otto Spiegelberg.

Four criteria for differentiating ovarian from other ectopic pregnancies:

1.    The gestational sac is located in the region of the ovary.

2.    The ectopic pregnancy is attached to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.

3.    Ovarian tissue in the wall of the gestational sac is proved histologically.

4.    The tube on the involved side is intact.

choices.text: Administration of insulin to prevent macrosomia
Cesarean delivery at 39 weeks to prevent shoulder dystocia
Kick counts and routine return visit in 1 week

questions.text: A 40-year-old G3P2 obese patient at 37 weeks presents for her routine OB visit. She has gestational diabetes that is controlled with diet. She reports that her fasting and postprandial sugars have all been within the normal range. Her fetus has an estimated fetal weight of 3kg by Leopold maneuvers. Which of the following is the best next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Kick counts and routine return OB visit in 1 week

In general, women with gestational diabetes, who do not require insulin, seldom need early delivery or other interventions. There is no consensus on whether antepartum fetal tesƟng is necessary in women with well-controlled gestational diabetes. Antepartum fetal testing is recommended for women with preexisting diabetes mellitus and those who require insulin therapy. There is no good evidence to support routine delivery before 40 weeks when glucose control is good and no other complications supervene. Caesarean delivery may be considered in women with gestational diabetes if the estimated fetal weight is 4500 g or more. Insulin therapy is indicated if diet cannot keep fasting glucose below 95 and 2-hour values below 120

questions.text:
A 31-year-old G1P0 woman at 39 weeks and 4 days presents to the labor and delivery unit, with regular contractions occurring every 3 to 5 minutes. Her contractions last 30 to 90 seconds. You determine her membranes have ruptured and admit her for active management of labor. The first stage of labor:

1)    Includes an active and latent phase 

2)    Ends when the cervix has completely dilated 

3)    Begins with the onset of Braxton Hicks contractions 

Answer using the code
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The first stage of labor includes an active and latent phase. Braxton Hicks are irregular contractions that do not result in cervical change, which is common in the third trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not cut in episiotomy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Structures cut are 

1)    Posterior vaginal wall

2)    Superficial and deep transverse perinei

3)    Bulbospongiosus

4)    Parts of levator ani

5)    Branches of pudendal nerve and vessels 

6)    Subcutaneous tissue and skin

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions in an Rh negative pregnancy Anti D will not be given 

1)    Negative ICT

2)    MCA PSV >1.5

3)    Cordocenetsis 

Answer using the code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MCA PSV >1.5 in a Rh negative pregnancy indicate that she is already alloimmunized and is producing large amounts of antibodies. There is no point of giving Anti D to such a patient.

Once MCA PSV is more than 1.5  we need to look for fetal anemia which will be seen with cordocentesis and again giving Anti D after this is not rationalised as she is already alloimmunized.

questions.text: Match the teratogens with their corresponding findings in pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 31-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation complains of painful uterine contractions that are occurring every 3 to 4 minutes. Her cervix has changed from 1-cm dilation to 2-cm dilation over 3 hours. Which one of the following management plans is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient is still in the (normal) latent phase; the upper limit is 14 hours. A fetal scalp pH monitor is a method for obtaining a small amount of capillary blood from the fetal scalp to assess for fetal academia, a procedure that is very infrequently performed. It is not indicated in this scenario and does not aid in the progress of labor. Intravenous oxytocin enhances contraction strength and/or frequency, but does not affect cervical dilation. A cesarean delivery is considered if there is a disorder during the active phase of labor and not the latent phase.

choices.text: Schedule an amniocentesis for amniotic ﬂuid bilirubin at 16 weeks
Schedule UBS as soon as possible to determine fetal blood type

questions.text: Primigravida with Rh negative pregnancy presents for her antenatal visit at 16 weeks and was advised ICT she follows up with anti D antibody titer of 1:4. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Repeat title in 4 weeks

1.    In the same patient-blood grouping shows A negative, with an anti D antibody titer of 1:4- the most appropriate next step is to Repeat title in 4 weeks the In the management

Since this patient is a primi patient and her antibody titre is 1:4 which is below the critical titer of 1:16 so we should follow it by doing a repeat titre after every weekly ﬁrst , if the titer is rising then the frequency is increased to once every 2 weeks till it reaches or crosses critical titer when it should be followed with MCA Doppler to look for fetal anemia

questions.text: A woman comes to the physican for a prenatal visit. Examination reveals that her uterus is considerably larger than her gestational age would predict. An ultra-sound examination is ordered  and reveals that she has polyhydramnios. Which of the following congenital defects of the fetus would be most likely to be associated with this abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Polyhydramnios is the presence of excess amniotic ﬂuid. Because amniotic ﬂuid  is  normally swallowed by the fetus, esophageal atresia, an obstruction of the esophagus that prevents the fetus from swallowing the amniotic ﬂuid, an excess of ﬂuid is retained in the amniotic cavity.

questions.text: For detection of gestational diabetes mellitus, the critical cut-off of DIPSI criteria is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

For detection of gestational diabetes mellitus, the critical cut-off of DIPSI criteria is

B. 140mg% after 2 hours

DIPSI test is done at 24-28 weeks. Fasting is not needed. The blood sugar levels after 2 hours of giving 75 gm oral glucose is checked. If the value is 140 mg% or more then the patient is labelled as a case of GDM

choices.text: Risk of recurrence after one affected fetus is 10%

questions.text: With respect to the following image what is incorrect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is the frog eye sign of anencephaly 

The recurrence risk after 1 previous neural tube defect is upto 4% and after two previous the risk increases to 10%

choices.text: Tear of mucosa and muscle and external sphincter more  than 50%
Tear of mucosa muscle and external sphincter less than 50%
Tear of mucosa muscle and both internal and external sphinter
Tear of mucosa, muscle external sphincter and rectum

questions.text: Perineal tear grade 3b refers to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

First Degree: superficial injury to the vaginal mucosa that may involve the perineal skin.

Second Degree: first-degree laceration involving the vaginal mucosa and perineal body.

Third Degree: second-degree laceration with the involvement of the anal sphincter. This is further classified into three sub-categories:[3][4]

•    A: Less than 50% of the anal sphincter is torn.

•    B: Greater than 50% of the anal sphincter is torn.

•    C: External and internal anal sphincters are torn.

Fourth Degree: third-degree laceration involving the rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Among the drugs used for AMTSL which statement is not true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Large doses of oxytocin should not be given in bolus as it can cause severe hypotension. It should be given either as im dose or iv infusion.

choices.text: Oxygen requirement of tissues increases by 20%
Cardiac output Reaches maximum by 32 weeks

questions.text: All the following physiological changes are seen in pregnancy except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plasma osmolality decreases in pregnancy as water retention is much more than salt retention, it reduces by 10 mosm

All other statements are true

choices.text: 4gm i.v. In 20 % dilution plus 5gm im in each buttock (50%dilution)
4gm i.v in 50% dilution plus 5gm im in each buttock (20% dilution)
5gm i.v in 25% dilution plus 10gm im in any buttock (50% dilution)
2gm i.v. In 50% dilution plus 5gm im in any buttock (50% dilution

questions.text: A 27 year old primigravida has eclampsia, loading dose of mgso4 in Pritchard’s regimen to be given to her should be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

4gm i.v. In 20 % dilution plus 5gm im in each buttock (50%dilution)

MgSO4 is a toxic drug. It can cause respiratory depression. We must monitor respiratory rate, deep tendon reflexes and urine output

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravid woman, who plans to breastfeed, decides to have a home delivery. Immediately after the birth of a 4.1-kg  newborn, the patient experiences massive hemorrhage from extensive vaginal and cervical lacerations. She is brought to the nearest hospital in shock. Over the course of 2 hours, nine units of blood are transfused, and the patient’s blood pressure returns to a reasonable level. A hemoglobin value the next day is 7.5 g/dL, and three more units of packed red blood cells are given. The most likely late sequela to consider in this woman is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A disadvantage of home delivery is the lack of facilities to control postpartum hemorrhage. The woman described in the question delivered a large baby, suffered multiple soft tissue injuries, and went into shock, needing nine units of blood by the time she reached the hospital. Sheehan syndrome seems a likely possibility in this woman. This syndrome of anterior pituitary necrosis related to obstetric hemorrhage can be diagnosed by 1-week postpartum, as lactation fails to commence normally. Other symptoms of Sheehan syndrome include amenorrhea, atrophy of the breasts, and loss of thyroid and adrenal function.

choices.text: H ypoglycemia requiring multiple D50 injections

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1001 woman is at 34 weeks’ gestation and noted to be icteric. She also has nausea and vomiting and malaise. A diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy is made, and the obstetrician recommends immediate delivery. Which of the following is most consistent with acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: One of the following is a contraindication for forceps application:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ballotable head in Leopold 4

Ballotable head means the head is not yet engaged. In such condition, instrumental delivery is contraindicated.

questions.text: Implantation of fertilised ovum occurs on which day following fertilisation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Implantation usually begins by day 6 post fertilization and is completed by day 10

questions.text: A primi presents at 28 weeks and the following is the image of doppler obtained. Her non stress test shows no accelerations. What is the next course of action
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is reversal of end diastolic flow. Management of REDF at and beyond 32 weeks is termination of pregnancy BY CS . here POG is less than 32 weeks we will give steroids for fetal lung maturation and do daily intense fetal monitoring with DFMC, BPP an doppler

questions.text:
The initial prevention strategy for APLA in pregnancy will be 

1) Steroids 

2) Heparin 

3) Low dose apirin 

4) Progesterone support 

Which of the above is /are correct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The criteria for defining pregnancy morbidity in the diagnosis of APS are called as Sapporo or Sydney criteria women with APS defining thrombosis and lab criteria for APLA are prescribed LMWH and LOW DOSE ASPIRIN in pregnanc. Women with lab criteria for APLA and pregnancy losses should also be given combined therapy with LMWH and aspirin for women with lab criteria and preterm labour are given only low dose aspirin women who meet lab criteria but have no clinical criteria will be given only low dose aspirin

questions.text: Which leopold grip is shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is the fourth leopold also called as deep pelvic grip. It helps to confirm whether head is engaged or not and also to know about attitude of the fetus

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are required for registered medical practitioner to qualify for performing MTP as per revised rules of MTP act 

1) Certified for assisting at least 15 MTP in an authorised centre

2) Diploma or degree in OBG 

3) House surgeon training for 3 months in obgy 

4) Certified training for 6 months in laparoscopic surgeries 

Select the correct answer using the code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The revised MTP bill 2020  inclues the following 

1)    Advice of one doctor for MTP done up to 20 weeks 

2)    Advice of 2 doctors for MTP done between 20-24 weeks for women under certain categories and central government will notify these categories 

3)    Beyond 24 weeks will need a medical board to allow MTP

4)    Anytime during pregnancy on advice of one doctor if immediately necessary to save pregnant womans life

5)    Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorized by law 

There are no changes in the requirement of registered medical practitioner which are 

Should have completed 6 months of house surgency in obgy

More than 1 year experience in practice of gynaecology

Assisted RMP in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a hospital established or maintained by government for this purpose 

Holds a postgraduate degree or diploma in obgy

questions.text: Which of the following clinical conditions is not an indication for induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Placenta previa is a contraindication to labor because the placenta is ahead of the presenting part covering the cervix and vaginal deliver would result in hemorrhage. Intrauterine fetal demise, preeclampsia, chorioamnionitis, and postterm pregnancies are all indications to induce labor.

questions.text: You are delivering a 33-year-old G3P2 and encounter a shoulder dystocia. After performing the appropriate maneuvers, the baby finally delivers, and the paediatricians attending the delivery note the following . Which of the following is the baby’s most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Shoulder dystocias can be associated with significant fetal morbidity including brachial plexus palsies, clavicular fractures, and humeral fractures. Fractures of the clavicle and humerus usually heal rapidly and are clinically insignificant. Injury to the brachial plexus may be localized to the upper or lower roots. In Erb (or Erb-Duchenne) palsy, the upper roots of the brachial plexus are injured (C5-6), resulting in paralysis of the shoulder and arm muscles; the arm hangs limply to the side and is extended and internally rotated. In the case of Klumpke paralysis, the lower nerves of the brachial plexus are affected (C7-T1) and the hand is paralyzed.

questions.text: Match the columns with their correct usg parameter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The single best parameter for fetal growth is abdominal circumference. AC < 10th percentile is suggestive of IUGR while AC> 35cm is suggestive of macrosomia 

The best parameter for pregnancy dating is CRL ideally done between 7-10 weeks although it is used for pregnancy dating up to 14 weeks 

Level 2 usg can be done between 18-22 weeks it is the single most important usg to be done during pregnancy 

Amniocentesis should be done at and beyond 15 weeks as Early amniocentesis done between 11-14 weeks has higher risk of fetal loss

Placenta which is in lower uterine segment in early pregnancy should be reviewed at 32 weeks as most placenta will show migration to the upper segment due to differential growth of the uterus

questions.text:
Which are impending signs of eclampsia ( multiple correct type) 

1) Epigastric pain

2) Persistent pedal edema 

3) Blurred vision 

4) Headache
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The signs and symptoms of impending eclampsia are 

1)    Persistent and /or severe headache 

2)    Visual disturbances like blurred vision, scotomas, photophobia and even loss of vison 

3)    Upper abdominal or epigastric pain associated with nausea vomiting 

4)    Altered mental status 

They signify need for urgent evaluation, prompt treatment to prevent seizures and reduce blood pressure and delivery

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bleeding occurs in about 30% to 40% of pregnancies before 20 weeks’ gestation, with about half of these pregnancies ending in spontaneous abortion. A threatened abortion describes uterine bleeding that occurs without any cervical dilation or effacement. Inevitable abortion occurs when there is bleeding and cervical dilation, with or without rupture of membranes. Incomplete abortion is when only a portion of the products of conception have been expelled, and the cervix remains dilated. Incases where all fetal and placental tissue have been expelled, the cervix is closed, bleeding is minimal and uterine cramps have ceased, a diagnosis of complete abortion may be made. A missed abortion is one in which fetal death occurs before 20 weeks’ gestation without expulsion of any fetal or maternal tissue for at least 8 weeks thereafter. When a fetus is retained in the uterus beyond 5 weeks after fetal death, consumptive coagulability with hypofibrinogenemia may occur. This is uncommon, however in gestations of less than 14 weeks in duration.

choices.text: Can be used in out patient setting

questions.text: All the statements are true about the device shown except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is MVA syringe used for pregnancy termination by manual aspiration it generates a pressure of 660mmhg. It is used as an alternative to suction evacuation and does not need electricity and can be used upto  12 weeks.

questions.text: A woman undergoes sonographic evaluation for uterine –size date discrepancy. AFI turned out to be 36 and the image is shown below. which of the following is appropriate for evaluation of this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amniocentesis for fetal karyotype 

This is the double bubble sign characteristic of duodenal atresia. There is associated polyhydramnios due to defective swallowing. Duodenal atresia has a strong association with downs syndrome. Duodenal atresia can be an isolated condition (which means no other birth defect or condition occurs with it), but is also more common in infants with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). About one in three babies born with duodenal atresia has Down syndrome. These patients must undergo genetic analysis for the same.

questions.text: A lady after delivery was noted to have postpartum haemorrhage. On examination her uterine fundus was firm but lower segment was atonic for which she was given oxytocin and hemabate. Despite this she continued to bleed and a whole blood transfusion was started and bakri balloon tamponade was put. Despite this she continues to bleed. Her PR is 124 bpm and BP is 80/60mmhg. You perform a laparotomy and see atonic uterus . which of the following is a suitable next step  in this situation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)
